description: CoronaNet #R_3oEBNISrYfgxczT CoronaNet #R_b7VhUezFIi52qat The provincial government of East Java applied a closure of schools starting from March 16 - 29. The closure applies for senior high schools and vocational schools (SMA & SMK). It has been extended to April 5, and then April 19. On April 19, it was extended until June 1. On June 2, it was extended to an indefinite amount of time - individual zones may relax closure of schools if deemed safe. Trials for the opening of schools are to begin from August 18, announced August 12. UPDATE: Ending policy on August 18.

description: The Indonesian government releases a document that outlines the distribution of vaccines produced by PT Bio Farma on 2 January 2021. The distribution will begin once the vaccine has obtained a license from the National Food and Drug Agency and will be conducted in this order: 1) healthcare workers, 2) the military, police, state officials who are in direct contact with the public, and the elderly; 3) people who are socio-economically vulnerable; and 4) the general public.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Administering of the vaccine (i.e. giving people the vaccine shot)
type_vac_mix: This distribution policy is not about mixing and matching of different vaccines.
type_vac_group: Certain populations based on demographic characteristics/epidemiological risk given preference for vaccinations
type_vac_who_pays: Vaccine is subsidized by the government for all individuals
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Priority Group 1: Essential medical workers; Priority Group 2: Government officials,People of a certain age; Priority Group 3: Other population; Priority Group 4: Other population
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

Indonesian Immigration has announced that foreign nationals who arrived on the “visa-on-arrival” mechanisms whose visas have expired with need to take the following steps within 30 days from July 13:

Those who arrived on “visa-on-arrival” (VKSK) may, within 30 days from July 13, apply for an extension, but per this policy will only receive an extension while the pandemic status continues and there are no flights available for you to return to the United States. description: People arriving in or leaving Java or traveling within Java by air must present a negative result from a reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) within 72 hours before departure or a rapid antigen test taken within 48 hours before departure. Passengers entering Bali via air travel must present a negative result from an RT-PCR taken within 48 hours before departure or a rapid antigen test taken within 24 hours before departure. Entrants for both regions by land or sea routes must present a negative result from an RT-PCR test or a rapid antigen test taken within 72 hours before departure.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: The Indonesian COVID-19 task force enacts a regulation from April 1st, 2021, that mandates people travelling via airplanes within the country to take COVID-19 tests. The acceptable tests are RT-PCR tests (which must be taken at maximum 3 x 24 hours before departure), rapid tests (which must be taken at most 2 x 24 hours before departure), and GeNose C19 (which must be taken at the airport prior to departure). Exceptions apply to travel to Bali, which requires valid tests under 2 x 24 hours prior to departure.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Indonesian COVID-19 taskforce announces an internal border restriction policy that will take place from April 1st, 2021. The policy obliges people traveling by sea to take COVID-19 tests at maximum 3 x 24 hours prior to departure. The accepted tests are RT-PCR tests, antigen rapid tests, and GeNose C19 (which needs to be taken at the port prior to departure). Exceptions apply to travelers traveling to Bali, who will be subject to stricter regulation.

The accepted tests are RT-PCR tests and antigen rapid tests which must be taken at most 2 x 24 hours prior to departure, and the GeNose C19 which needs to be taken at the airport, seaport, and/or terminal prior to departure. The policy takes place from April 1st, 2021.

The accepted tests are RT-PCR tests and antigen rapid tests which must be taken at most 2 x 24 hours prior to departure, and the GeNose C19 which needs to be taken at the airport, seaport, and/or terminal prior to departure. description: On March 31 2020, the Indonesian government signed a Government Regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The regulation allows "Large-Scale Social Restrictions" as defined in Law No.6/2020 on Health Quarantine to take into effect, under the condition that regions wishing to apply the policy obtain approval from the Ministry of Health/central government. The law covers several types of policies, such as isolation, house quarantine, regional quarantine, large-scale social restrictions and lockdowns, etc.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: A general law on health quarantine (UU No. 6/2018). The law requires a regulation to allow it to take into effect (which will be coded as update afterwards). The law covers several types of policies, such as isolation, house quarantine, regional quarantine, large-scale social restrictions, etc. The law was put into effect on March 31 by the issuance of regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 3 2020, Indonesia's health minister signed Peraturan Menteri No. 9/2020 on the Guidelines for Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The document outlines the criteria that local administrations should fulfill in order to enact the large-scale social restriction (lockdown) policy in their region. These criteria include significant rate and/or number of COVID-19 cases and deaths as well as comparative studies or proof from other regions or countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

The policy has been extended several times, to May 12, to May 19, to July 2, to July 16, to August 1, and then to August 16, to August 31, to September 29, to October 27. description: The Indonesian government enacts a 'Pemberlakuan Pembatasan Kegiatan Masyarakat Berbasis Mikro' - loosely translated as lockdown that is implemented until the micro level - from February 9 - 22, 2021. This policy mandates that micro-level units of government, such as districts and sub-districts, villages, and RT/RW (neighbourhoods). Besides a lockdown, the policy also includes different intensities of health monitoring, quarantine, curfews, and closure of public spaces depending on different levels of virus spread in the respective areas (i.e. green, yellow, orange, and red zones). The policy is enacted after a previously similar policy, which was enacted until the city/regency level.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Indonesia is providing an IDR 10.3 trillion stimulus to the domestic tourism sector in the form of discounted ticket prices for 10 tourist destinations, such as  Batam, Denpasar, Yogyakarta, Labuan Bajo, Lombok, Malang, Manado, Lake Toba (Silangit Airport), Tanjung Pandan, and Tanjungpinang, which applies  from March to May 2020. 

Ticket prices for low-cost airlines are discounted by 50%, medium-service by 48%, and full-service by 45%. Specifically for this ticket price discount, the stimulus fund comes from the IDR 444.39 billion-state budget (APBN) for a discounted value of 30% and 25% of passengers per flight. Additionally, there are additional ticket discounts paid by Angkasa Pura I and Angkasa Pura II in the amount of Rp100 billion and PT Pertamina (Persero) in the amount of Rp260 billion through avtur price discounts, so the total ticket price stimulus is IDR 960 billion so that the ticket price can be discounted by 50%.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: This is to provide stimulus to the domestic tourism sector in the form of discounted ticket prices.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The OJK is issuing OJK Regulation No.11/POJK.03/2020 on National Economic Stimulus as a Countercyclical Policy of Coronavirus Disease 2019 Infection Impact (“POJK 11/2020”). POJK 11/2020 primarily is intended to support economic growth for debtors impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, including for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (“MSME”) debtors, conducted through policies on asset quality determination and credit restructuring and financing. Based on POJK 11/2020, banks may implement policies to support the economic growth stimulus by conducting the above by still considering the implementation of risk management of banks and also having guidelines to establish debtors and MSME debtors based on the criteria and sectors impacted by COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: This policy falls into economic resources. It is issued by the Otoritas Jasa Keuangan (OJK).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Indonesia's Ministry of Law and Human Rights issued a policy to release around 30,000 prisoners as an effort to prevent the spread of Covid-19 on March 30, 2020. The prisoners must meet several conditions in order to be eligible for the release: a) have served 2/3 of their sentences by December 31, 2020; b) for minors, having served 1/3 of their sentences by December 31, 2020; c) is not affected by PP 99/2012 (for prisoners applying for assimilation), not affected by PP No. 12/1999 (for those applying for integration), not serving subsidiary sentences, and is not a foreign national; d) must stay at home; and e) obtain a letter of assimilation from the head of their respective correctional facilities (or letter of integration from the general director for those applying for integration).
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: The policy releases prisoners ahead of their sentence time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Indonesia is providing a new fiscal stimulus (Vol 2) of IDR 22.9 trillion. The new stimulus includes the following:

1. Income Tax Law No. 21 (PPh Pasal 21) - Up to 100% or IDR 200 million income tax exemption for workers in process manufacturing industry from April 2020 to September 2020.
2. Income Tax Law No. 22 (PPh Pasal 22) - Import tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
3. Income Tax Law No. 25 (PPh Pasal 25) - Income tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
4. Value-added tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Fiscal Stimulus Vol 2 of IDR 22.9 trillion by the Ministry of Finance.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Indonesia is providing an additional stimulus package amounting to IDR 405.1 trillion (2.6% of GDP) with the following details as announced on 31 Marc , 2020:
1. IDR 75 trillion for the health sector, which includes protection for healthcare workers, purchase of medical equipments, reparation of healthcare facilities, and doctors' incentives.
2. Social Safety Net of IDR 110 trillion consisted of food assistance programs, pre-employment cards, and electricity.
3. Tax reliefs and KUR (Credits for People's Businesses) amounting to IDR 75 trillion, which includes permanent reductions of the corporate income tax rate from 25 percent to 22 percent in 2020-21 and 20 percent starting in 2022. 
4. Funding for the national economic recovery program amounting to IDR 150 trillion.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: Issued by the Ministry of Finance, this is the third COVID-19-related fiscal stimulus after the first 2 fiscal stimulus amounting to IDR 33.2 trillion.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 6, 2020, the Indonesian government rolled out a health protocol on handling the Covid-19. The release of this health protocol is accompanied with 4 other protocols (on communication, border monitoring, education, as well as transportation and public spaces).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
type_text: The policy is a protocol that outlines how the public should act in responding to the pandemic (and who to reach out to).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 6, 2020, the Indonesian government released a protocol for public spaces and transportations. The protocol consists of procedures that authorities/officials should follow to prevent the transmission of the Covid-19 in these areas, including sanitation, health screening, air circulation, and limitations on physical contact. Targets mentioned in the protocol: transportation (and its facilities/transit), large-scale activies, markets, restaurants.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
type_text: The protocol outlines precedures that authorities/officials should follow in particular areas to prevent the transmission of the Covid-19.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On March 6, 2020, the Indonesian government released a communication protocol that outlines how government officials should convey information on the Covid-19 pandemic to the public. The protocol prescribes the creation of a communication team and that government officials should abide by the following narratives in making statements: a) that the government is serious and capable in handling the pandemic; b) that people should remain calm but aware; and c) that the Covid-19 can be cured. The release of this protocol was accompanied by 4 other protocols.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: The policy is a guideline for government officials who are going to release information on the Covid-19 to the public. I regard this a public policy as it affects the public is going to receive official statements about the pandemic and the public's responses to it. (for context, the issue of the Indonesian government's transparency is currently criticized)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: For Indonesian citizens who have travelled to the Iran, Italy, Holy See, Spain, France, Germany, Switzerland, United Kingdom, an additional screening shall be carried out by the Port Health Authority upon arrival. description: Travelers from Europe and Australia traveling to Indonesia, either directly or by transit through another country, shall quarantine for five days. Indonesian citizens shall be quarantined at the special government quarantine facility, foreign nationals shall perform self-isolation at the hotel appointed by the Government of the Republic of Indonesia, at their own expense. After the 5-day quarantine, Indonesian citizens and foreign nationals shall be re-examined by taking a RT-PCR test. The above regulation will be enforced on 22 December 2020 until 8 January 2020, with full implementation starting from 24 December 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The city council of Ambon issued a policy to restrict the operation hours of supermarkets, shopping centers, minimarkets, retail shops, cafes, and "warkop" from April 5, 2020. These shops may only operate from 9:00 AM to 8:00 PM, while those who usually operate 24 hours may only open 2 branches per county after 8:00 PM. Cinemas and karaokes will be closed.

description: On March 4, the DKI Jakarta administration extended its closure of recreational sites until April 19. It has been extended to April 19.

description: The provincial government of Bali called for the closure of tourism sites from March 20. The policy was gradually ended since early July. description: On April 6, 2020, Indonesia's Ministry of Religious Affairs issued guidelines for religious activities in the upcoming month of Ramadan. The guidelines include recommendations that a) Muslims have meals individually or with their nuclear families; b) Muslims not have congregational prayers, including Eid prayers (at the mosque where mass gatherings occur); c) all iftar and other ceremonial gatherings be suspended; d) Muslims not conduct Iktikaf at mosques; e) ritual parades be suspended; f) 'halal bi halal' be conducted through calls; and g) Muslims pay their zakat before the month of Ramadan starts.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 31, 2020, the Indonesian government signed a Government Regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The regulation allows "Large-Scale Social Restrictions" as defined in Law No.6/2020 on Health Quarantine to take into effect, under the condition that regions wishing to apply the policy obtain approval from the Ministry of Health/central government. UPDATE: The original entry was for a an umbrella law on health quarantine. This entry is for the government regulation that allows the measures in the original law to take into effect.

Cars may only carry 50% of its total seat capacity.

Healthcare, food production and distribution, energy, communication and information technology, banking and finances, logistics, hotels, construction, and strategic industries are allowed to open with a maximum of 50% capacity on-site. The policy takes into effect from September 14-28, 2020.

description: As part of the province's second lockdown, the provincial government of DKI Jakarta closes non-essential business services, from September 14 - 28, 2020. These include full closures of recreational services and arenas, public sports areas, parks, and party (i.e. wedding) venues. Restaurants and cafes can open for takeaways and deliveries only. Certain non-essential businesses may operate with a limited capacity on-site of 25%. UPDATE: The business restriction policy was extended, September 28 - October 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

Healthcare, food production and distribution, energy, communication and information technology, banking and finances, logistics, hotels, construction, and strategic industries are allowed to open with a maximum of 50% capacity on-site. The policy takes into effect from September 14-28, 2020. UPDATE: On September 25, the regulation was extended and to take into effect from September 28 - October 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
